Alex,
I was wondering if you could expand somewhat on your paper's stagin=
g process referenced in section 5.4? I am attempting to distinguish it from=
 Neat's complexification process.
Thanks,
Andy

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> =C2=A0If the gradie=
nt-based optimizer modify the phenotype, at each genotype evaluation, yes, =
I would see this as an iterated transformation. Good example of this would =
be optimization of a perceptron, for a supervised learning problem. The gen=
otype would be the structure of perceptron, and some parameters for an init=
ialization heuristic. The initial phenotype would be a perceptron decoded f=
rom the genotype. Then, the development would be a retro-propagation traini=
ng of that perceptron. Retro-propagation is a gradient-based optimization, =
using local informations. I'm sure such a thing crossed many minds ^^
> 
> =
If the gradient-based optimizer modify the genotype, no. So if the genotype=
 is directly the weights of a fixed-topology perceptron, nope.
> 
> I can p=
ost my HyperNEAT setup quite soon, and I should have done this since a whil=
e, lazy me... I had to do some a bit of engineering in the code, to make it=
 compilable on the cluster I was using. So although it's the genuine origin=
al HyperNEAT code, some cosmetic chirurgy happened. More important, you got=
 the fitness function for the problem. =C2=A0I just need to write a little =
bit of documentation on how to compile and use the whole mess. I'll post it=
 on my website and send an=C2=A0announcement=C2=A0of this. Can be done with=
in few days.
> 
> Cheers,
> Alex
> 
> ________________________________
> De=
=C2=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl2@...>
> =C3=80=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Envoy=
=C3=A9 le : Mardi 15 Novembre 2011 8h51
> Objet=C2=A0: Re: Re : Re : Re : [=
neat] Any Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is The Ou=
tput?
> 
> 
> =C2=A0 
> 
> 
> Alex,
> If an individual maps to a point eval=
uation of the design space, and the local jacobian of the fitness landscape=
 is such that an added local gradient based sub-optimization task follows a=
 trajectory resulting in an improved fitness associated w/ an updated indiv=
idual, would that satisfy the classification requirements associated w/ "im=
plicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, would you consider uploading your updated=
 version of Hyperneat used in your study to the group file repository?
> Th=
anks,
> Andy
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide=
@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > =C3=82=C2=A0 I'm not 100% sure to get the whole m=
eaning of your question, so I might answer a bit off-target ^^
> > 
> > =C3=
=82=C2=A0 In that paragraph about the taxonomy (end of page 4), I mention "=
local information". It's not a gradient, as in "gradient based optimization=
", that is, a clue on the local geometry of the objective function. By "loc=
al information", I mean, *any* kind of local feedback of the behavior of th=
e phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, it could be, say, the local air p=
ressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, it would be local heath flux. If =
we optimize a water pipe network, it would the local water flux and pressur=
e.
> > 
> > 
> > =C3=82=C2=A0Then, does this local information feeback turn=
s "external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It=
's quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genotyp=
e as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have many=
 many ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transfo=
rmation (many many development steps, each doing small changes in all possi=
ble ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation st=
ep). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved emb=
ryogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than =
a sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolve=
d embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a =
few steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it'=
s a rethoritical remark.
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > 
> > Alex
> > 
> > 
> > _____=
___________________________

imization of the design space transition the classification definition from=
 "external non-evolved embryogeny" to "implicit evolved embryogeny"? BTW, I=
 am attracted to your more flexible taxonomy, as I have never been fully co=
mfortable with the spatial transformation constraint assumption.
> > Thanks=
